awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Resolving Outstanding Questions in Spin-Exchange Optical Pumping of 129Xe
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic resonance imaging of gas inside the lungs or other similar spaces where gases can be admitted utilizes as the active medium noble gases that have had their magnetic nuclei aligned to point in the same direction, a process known as noble-gas MRI.  Effective use of the process today is only possible if the sensitivity is enhanced by spin-exchange optical pumping (SEOP) for preparing the spin-polarized noble gas samples (helium-3 or xenon-129) to be used in the imaging procedure. This research focuses on the SEOP process itself, in which angular momentum is transferred first from light to alkali-metal atoms that absorb the light and then transfer the momentum to the noble-gas atoms through collisions. The collisions align (or polarize) the magnetic nuclei, bringing their north and south magnetic poles in mutual alignment, thereby rendering them useful for MRI studies. This project will address some open questions relating to how the efficiency of SEOP depends on the laser power, the laser bandwidth, the choice of alkali-metal atoms, and the pressure of the buffer gas in the gas mixtures. SEOP of xenon-129 (129Xe) is of particular interest because it is less well understood, and because it may supersede helium-3 as the atom of choice for noble-gas MRI. The industrial partner for this GOALI project, Polarean, Inc., is at the forefront of 129Xe-MRI technological development. This project will enable university researchers to collaborate with Polarean, Inc. to study physics issues related to SEOP of 129Xe, and to use the resulting knowledge to improve a commercial polarization device. 

The three main research aims are: (1) Pushing Rubidium-129Xe SEOP toward ultra-fast rates: The goal is to demonstrate and implement quantitative gains in the spin-exchange efficiency in the less-studied low-buffer-gas-density regime (~ 0.1 amagat). The ultra-narrow OptiGrate laser allows significant light deposition even for the much narrower rubidium D1 absorption line in this regime. (We note that Optigrate is a second industrial collaborator in this project.) (2) Direct comparison of rubidium to cesium for use in SEOP: The goal is to make quantitative measurements of Rb-129Xe and Cs-129Xe SEOP parameters using the common platform of the dual-head high-power Rb/Cs diode laser, in order to determine whether and to what degree Cs is advantageous. (3) The role of alkali-metal clusters in limiting SEOP efficiency: The goal is to obtain direct evidence for these potentially deleterious nanoclusters in a SEOP polarizer and incorporate their effects into the "standard model" for 129Xe SEOP. Meeting each of these goals has a direct impact on the efficiency of 129Xe SEOP, elucidating some interesting (and heretofore elusive) physics while also leading to improved production of HP 129Xe for applications such as lung MRI.

por.por_cntn:
This project focus on the physics and techniques of producing hyperpolarized noble gases. The nuclei of these gases possess an intrinsic property called spin, which makes each atom into an atomic magnet that can be detected in much the same way as the motion of an ordinary magnet can create an electrical current in a loop of wire. Polarization is the process of aligning the poles (north and south) of these atomic magnets, thereby enhancing the electrical signal that they can produce. The polarization is fragile and will "relax" back to an unpolarized equilibrium state, which has very little sensitivity to detection. However, before this relaxation occurs, it is possible for a human to breathe in a mixture containing such a gas (we study the stable, nonradioactive isotope, 129Xe). Hyperpolarized noble gases, especially xenon, also have several important applications to magnetometry, gyroscopy, precision measurements, and biophysics. Understanding how they are produced, measuring the associated cross sections and relaxation rates, and working directly with commercial partners all contribute to fostering these applications, especially (in our case) to lung MRI, where our GOALI partner, Polarean, Inc., is commercializing large-scale production of hyperpolarized 129Xe for medical imaging. The spin physics here is rich and complex; the experiments involve vacuum, rf, magnetic resonance, laser, and optical detection techniques. Students and other trainees learn and apply electronics, high-vacuum techniques, and even some glass-blowing skills, all in the context of table-top measurements on apparatus built and tested in the laboratory. These skills translate well both to academic and non-academic positions for our graduates.

There were two main scientific/technical outcomes; both set the stage for productive science in the subsequent award period. The angular-momentum transfer that happens during the collisional exchange of spin between an alkali-metal electron and a noble gas nucleus has a uniquely quantum mechanical feature that speeds up the process by two to three orders of magnitude (in the case of 129Xe) over what one might expect classically. Our first outcome was a careful measurement of this "enhancement factor" for both Rb-Xe and Cs-Xe pairs. Both results were published in Physical Review A. The second, more technical outcome was the construction and testing of a set of integrated tools that enable careful measurements of spin-destruction and spin-exchange rates for the Rb-Xe and Cs-Xe pairs across a wide range of gas densities, gas compositions, and temperatures. These tools include stabilizing an open-geometry Helmholtz-coil magnetic field down to about 5 ppm, converting a commercial NMR spectrometer to be able to do pulsed EPR on alkali-metals with magnetic excitation and optical detection, and the direct measurement of  alkali-metal densities in situ in a vapor cell. This combination enables measurements of the relevant rates in at least two independent ways, allowing us to evaluate and eliminate systematic errors. A technical publication on the stabilzed Helmholtz field is in preparation. We will publish the other technical aspects as part of the next  publication on measured spin-exchange rates and efficiencies.

Three students earned MS degrees on the project.  Mr. Jeffrey Jensen took a position as an Analytical Scientist with the chemical company Moses Lake Industries in Washington state. Mr. David Morin is a Systems Security Engineer at Teledyne Technologies in Los Angeles. Mr. Kyle Elsasser was hired into a "Scientist II" position by Electro Magnetic Applications, Inc. in Lakewood, Colorado. The project employed a post-doctoral fellow,  Dr. Sheng Zou, who is now a research faculty member at Beihang University in Beijing,. The project's current post-doc, Dr. Adnan Nahlawi, has been promoted to a research faculty position and also teaches one course per academic year. The project also supported Ph.D. student Zahra Armanfard, who is scheduled to graduate in Fall 2023.

The project further built the relationship between our research group and Polarean, Inc., to the point where we continue to work together under the subsequent award. Under the current award, we progressed most of the way to understanding the difference in Xe-Rb and Xe-Cs spin-destruction rates in the gas-density regime of interest for the Polarean polarizer--an important piece of information for understanding which alkali-metal partner is optimal for producing liter-quantities of hyperpolarized 129Xe. In the next grant period, one of the first projects we will work on is understanding how the vapor cells used in the Polarean polarizer are "seasoned," meaning how they reach an equilibrium of alkali-metal vapor density at a specified temperature and laser power. It is clear that this process takes time (sometimes days) because of the complex interactions of the alkali metal with the cell wall; this costs time and money for those installing machines in the field. We are working on a way to "pre-season" cells reliably and rapidly, so that when they are delivered to a machine in the field they perform within specified parameters right away.
